Reproduces in 2022.3 builds. In 2022.2, the behaviour is slightly different, but still the open file is not focused after IDE restart .

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Launch IDE and make sure "Reopen projects on startup" setting is ON
  2. Open a project and a file
  3. Open Structure tool window
  4. Restart IDE

Expected result:
After IDE startup, Nav bar shows path to the open file, Structure tool window shows structure of the file, caret is in the file.

Actual result:
Nav bar shows project title, Structure tool windows says "No structure", no caret is in the file.

{width = 500}

","created":1633097182249,"updated":null,"id":"27-5242059","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"victorrentea","name":"Victor Rentea","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

I did found a workaround for this:

  1. Locate the -javadoc.jar in your m2 repository loaded by IntelliJ
  2. Unzip the folder
  3. Set the library javadoc URL to point to the folder (don't forget to add the file:// prefix)

Attached are pictures.

Replace the .jar with the unzipped folder

Hope that helps !

IntelliJ installation info :

IU-203.5981.155, JRE 11.0.9+11-b1145.21x64 JetBrains s.r.o., OS Linux(amd64) v5.9.10-100.fc32.x86_64, screens 1920.0x1080.0

What steps will reproduce the issue?

  1. Open java source containing javadoc with embedded html img tag (In my case, spring-reactor 3.4.0 flux class)
  2. Switch to reader mode (should be done by default)

What is the expected result?

API doc inline preview should display images embedded in documentation, as documentation window is able to show them (see attached screenshot)

What happens instead?

API doc preview will display broken images

Let's assume the following code:

kt
@Service 
class MyService(val project: Project) {
  var counter = 0

  init {
    project.messageBus.connect().subscribe(Topics.MyTopic, object: ControlEventListener {
      override fun beforeEvent() {
        counter += 1
      }

      override fun afterEvent() {
        counter -= 1
        assert(counter)
      }
   }
}

This code looks safe, but it's actually not even if Topics.MyTopic is marked with immidiateDelivery.
If the initiation of the service happens between before and after events, this code will break.

Possible solutions

Code aware

We can add something like if (counter == 0) return in the afterEvent. This is actually what implemented in one of the maven subscriptions, but the client should be aware about this issue and not to forget add this code.

Change subscription to xml

This approach was implemented in IDEA-324087 when we faced this issue. However, this will mean extracting the listener in the separate class and initialization of MyService on the first event. This may cause the initialization of the service earlier than it should be used.

For the moment, I have no idea on how to properly fix this issue, but I've created this ticket to keep the track on it.

IU-232.8453.116, JRE 17.0.7+7-b1000.2x64 JetBrains s.r.o., OS Mac OS X(aarch64) v13.4, screens 3456.0x2234.0, 5120.0x2880.0; Retina

","tags":[],"id":"25-4634688","$type":"Issue","workItems":[]}, {"created":1346257096746,"resolved":null,"attachments":[],"project":{"shortName":"IDEA","$type":"Project"},"updated":1688730613309,"reporter":{"login":"peter","$type":"User"},"summary":"Keep non-shareable project files (workspace.xml, *.iws) separately from shareable (.idea)","comments":[{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Christopher_Rodier","name":"Christopher Rodier","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
One of the critical artifacts when doing rapid development across many multiple Java and other projects and teams, are the Run Configurations. Often, nuggets of key information, be it the System -D location of the log4j XML file, and others, are in the Run Configs.

Even if devoid of settings other than the Java Class, this is still a breadcrumb for other team mates that work on or join the project, as to what runs, and how to run it in various environments.

To work around the standard .git configuration is I setup a detailed .gitignore and this travels with me. But there are often new files added by plugins. What I need to do is ignore the entire .idea folder, as this is the default, but store the Run Configurations elsewhere.

Could you please make two changes to the platform:

1. By Default, put the run configurations in the .idea directory.
2. Make a checkbox at the Editor level, which puts them in a folder, and the ability to set that folder.
3. Make this something that can be picked up from POM.xml in Java in the Maven Plugin
4. Give the ability on the dialog to specify an alternate location.

This way, I can get out of the business of maitnaining .gitignore files. It is a seeming omission from the idea of using this as a platform with shared config between developers unless I am missing something.
","created":1433768065112,"updated":1433768099708,"id":"27-1010705","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Christopher_Rodier","name":"Christopher Rodier","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
More thoughts...

_on POM FILES_

We use POM files as projects, in the biz, and in my office. You could add a property which the IntelliJ POM parser was aware of, which if set like:

<property name="idea.runConfig.folder" value="runConfigs"/>

.. would direct IDEA to update the location from ./idea/runConfigurations to <project root>/runConfigs.

This way the run configs are out of .idea, and the location is managed by the POM.xml. We would in fact put it in a parent POM to all of our java projects. This would change the location in the .iml.

I think this is straightforward and the platform would benefit from run Configs being outside the .idea folder.

Also, I think they should default to <projectRoot>/.runConfigs now that I think of it, such that .idea is the platforms playground for non-committed files, but as I said before, the run configs are key artifact of the development process, and should usually be checked in and shared.

Currently you _promote_ not sharing them, because .idea is part of .gitignore as it should be. You need to _promote_ sharing them, as a best practice. By default they should be created, and shared. People don't know abut this terrific feature, and view run configs as disposable, which they should not be.

Best Regards,
Chris

I would suggest the following SIMPLE feature to fix super-annoying updates and syncs of workspace.xml: use these files only once: reading it when app started and writing to it when app closes. Every other read/write should be done to a corresponding copy within the AppData Folder...
additionally, this feature can be an option and/or can be automatically activated if the app detects that the project is within dropbox/google drive etc...
Best
Erland

Feedback:

I just want to echo the feedback of this being a hot mess. Why on earth would you intertwine personal, often secret settings, with global ones in not only the same folder, but often in the same files? Please figure out a better way to do this. The default JetBrains .gitignore does not ignore .idea/workspace.xml files in nested folders, for instance.
Please separate personal files from non-personal and make the default ignore rules a one- or at most two-liner that is fail-safe. The current situation is horrible.

...

The idea directory contained some files that should be versioned and some that did not so managing the .gitignore file was more complex than necessary.
It would be better if the idea directory provided a simple wildcard friendly way of excluding all files that should not be versioned. Maybe have a .idea/volatile

...

Any chance of a review of the .idea directory layout and its contents? I want to move shared settings under version control, but at this point it's still less problematic and error-prone to just import Gradle build files and hand-customize from there. It just doesn't scale, as we move to smaller microservice projects, composite Gradle builds, and more engineers.

","created":1487858492761,"updated":null,"id":"27-1945895","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"mers","name":"Emerson Farrugia","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
Serge Baranov thanks for pointing me to this issue, and since it's open I'll add additional feedback here.

Vladimir Krivosheev I don't quite know where to begin specifying details. And that's part of the problem; the .idea directory doesn't "fit in my head". I'm not familiar with what's in it well enough to make educated decisions on what should be under version control and what shouldn't. Which leaves me with two pragmatic options; follow https://www.gitignore.io/api/intellij blindly and hope I'm not sharing user-specific stuff or causing breakages, or leave .idea entirely out of source control.

I think a good first step would be to provide a blessed .gitignore that wouldn't lead to unintentional credential leaks or breakages, and still share the most valuable configuration files like data sources and run configurations.

This might dovetail well with a clear approach to the Share checkboxes in the IDE, e.g. in Run Configurations. It would be great to assume that clicking that checkbox means that whatever is being shared is now under source control and safe to share.

","created":1493054443207,"updated":null,"id":"27-2123044","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Bjorn.Pettersen","name":"Bjorn Pettersen","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
.idea/local/ for non-shareable files would be great, but really.. Pycharm ought to know, by itself / for itself, which of the project files it itself has generated that can be checked in.

In addition, if it was possible to use environment variables for private/local data, and universal path separators, then much of this could be avoided. E.g. my misc.xml starts with

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project version="4">
  <component name="ProjectRootManager" version="2" project-jdk-name="Python 2.7.11 virtualenv at C:\srv\venv\myproject" ...

The local path C:\srv\venv\myproject could have been written as ${WORKON_HOME}/myproject since the WORKON_HOME environment variable always points to the local location of the virtualenvs.

Anyways, the way it is now I've got 105 projects asking me if dbSettings.xml, codeStyles/bla-bla, etc. should be added to version control. How should I know? I'll have to open each of them to figure out if they contain, or are likely to contain in the future, local paths or credentials. This is a pop-up(!) that comes when opening the project and I want to start working. And I have to find the file in another editor to view it since I have a pop-up blocking my IDE interaction... (*sigh*). How about at least moving this question to the commit screen instead?

","created":1525874736263,"updated":null,"id":"27-2860759","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Kirill.Likhodedov","name":"Kirill Likhodedov","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

.idea already has a bad reputation of a folder containing some strange files which nobody knows which are used for, and thus it is added as a template to .gitignore at gitignore.io. Moverover, .idea starts with a dot, which is a common prefix for hidden (and thus non-shareable) files.

Therefore AFAIK current idea is the opposite to what was described in this issue description: to move shareable items out from .idea to some other folder with a more clear name. But it should happen only after all cleaning activities (such as "no files in default state" and others) by Vladimir and Nik are completed.

Build: 2023.1, 232.4670 (win11)

Preconditions: 'Line: column number' widget is on (View > Appearance > Status Bar Widgets)

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Open File1, File2
  2. Detach File2
  3. Set cursor to some line in File2 > Check 'Line: column number' widget

Actual result:

'Line: column number' and 'Read-Only attribute' widgets are absent in status bar for the detached tab

Expected result:

In 2022.3.3: 'Line: column number', 'Read-Only attribute' widgets are displayed in status bar for the detached tab

@Vladimir Krivosheev hi! Seems that this problem is a side effect of async open file on navigation.
I see that editors are open open slowly only for SVG files (or other with heavy preview like markdown). Other code files with simple editors open fast.
As I understand the slowdown is caused by initialisation of every opened editor during opening the next. Can we skip it somehow and initialise only one that will be selected as a result?
As an experiment I disabled Move focus to editor when Enter is pressed in Advanced Settings | Project View, and editors start to open much faster. So, for example we can focus only last editor, not all in a row.

","created":1683792255908,"updated":null,"id":"27-7325680","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"develar","name":"Vladimir Krivosheev","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
      for (Navigatable navigatable : navigatables) {
        navigatable.navigate(requestFocus);
      }

Here we cannot pass requestFocus only to the last navigatable, as we do not know whether navigation was performed successfully.
It is related to my changes, and now, after some related fixes, I cannot reproduce the issue.

Build: #IU-233.1263 (Runtime version: 17.0.7+7-b1023.5 amd64)
Not reproduced: #IU-232.8453.116

Prereq:
Enable Global menu (Window decorations > Titlebar Buttons > Application menu)

STR:

  1. Enable Old UI
  2. Open a project
  3. Open global menu, try to open submenus

Result:
The menu blinks, submenus appears not each time and only for a moment, sometimes the menu in a separate toolbar appears instead on system burger.

Build: 233.817 (win11, KDE)

Not reproduced: 2023.2

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Open IDE
  2. Zoom IDE (on win: Alt + Shift + =)
  3. Pay attention to the toolbar
  4. RMB on toolbar > Add to main toolbar
  5. Select some action
  6. Pay attention to the toolbar

Actual result:

Toolbar content blinks on zoom or adding a new action

Expected result:

Toolbar content does not blink on zoom or adding a new action

Build: #IU-233.1192 (win, mac)

STR:

  1. Enable New UI
  2. Open a project
  3. Remove all items from File | Settings | Appearance & Behavior | Menus and Toolbars | Main Toolbar > Left, Center and Right groups
  4. Restart the IDE

Expected result:
The main toolbar appears with the correct (reduced) height.

Actual result:
The main toolbar appears with the normal height for a while and then jumps to get smaller:

Build: the described behavior reproduces at least since #IU-233.699; in #IU-233.630, IDE gets stuck on exiting Presentation mode (win, macOS)
Not reproduced in: #IU-232.8854

UPD: the issue doesn't reproduce if there are configs from previous versions at the first start of 233 build

Prereq:

  1. Remove all IDE config directories from the machine
  2. Launch IDEA 233 (without importing configs)

STR:

  1. Open a project
  2. Enter Presentation mode

Result:

Build: 233.385 (Ubuntu, KDE)

Steps to reproduce:

Case1:

  1. View > Appearance > Enter presentation mode
  2. Exit presentation mode
  3. Check project icon

Case 2:

  1. View > Appearance > Zoom IDE (several times)
  2. Check project icon

Actual result:

Sometimes project icon is cut (until widget is opened)

But it is reproduced very seldom, I caught it only twice for now)

Expected result:

Project icon is not cut when IDE is scaled

","created":1562330663458,"updated":1562330688458,"id":"27-3556479","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"lena","name":"Elena Pogorelova","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"
the problem is that the project files were not updated correctly for some reason - references to storish.iml were not renamed, causing
java.io.FileNotFoundException: File /Users/artur/Code/Sandbox/crud-world/.idea/storish.iml does not exist errors. Module file can't be loaded, so no information about project roots is available.
You need to either update the references in `.idea/modules.xml manually or remove the whole .idea folder and re-create the project files by opening /Users/artur/Code/Sandbox/crud-world folder in the IDE via File > Open

Note that you need to close the project and shut down the IDE prior to modifying .idea files
","created":1562332380775,"updated":1562332450531,"id":"27-3556587","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"user567999","name":"user567999","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

Thanks @Elena Pogorelova but I am not gonna dig in .idea files. This is IDE domain, something that the IDE should have taken care of. What I did was not any type of voo doo - it was a typical project Rename case, when you realize that the project you are creating should have a more suitable name. Apparently this basic case hasn't been tested enough.

Reproduced with WebStorm 2019.1.3. Steps are the following:

  • create simple Angular CLI project called untitled;
  • rename directory to crud-world;
  • rename project crud-world;
  • close the project;
  • the project in "recent projects" will be still named as untitled:
  • open the project.

WS-202.6948.73
renaming both project directory and project itself (from untitled22 to renamed) results in having 2 .idea folders: <projects dir>/untitled22/.idea and <projects dir>/renamed/.idea; the former doesn't include .iml files and refers to $PROJECT_DIR$/../renamed/.idea/renamed.iml in modules.xml, the latter has renamed.iml and a reference to non-existing untitled22.iml in its modules.xml

 <module fileurl="file://$PROJECT_DIR$/.idea/untitled22.iml" filepath="$PROJECT_DIR$/.idea/untitled22.iml" />

What steps will reproduce the problem?

  1. Create an Angular CLI project
  2. Right click the main project folder -> Refactor > Rename > Directory
  3. Right click the main project folder -> Refactor > Rename > Project Name (use the same name as for directory)
  4. Close the project and reopen

What is the expected result?
The project should be intact

What happens instead?

  1. The source files are gone:

  1. The breadcrumbs are enormously long - starting at hard disk root /

As this was Angular CLI project, I also did name replacements in angular.json. To no avail.
I think this is a bad joke, right?

???

???

???

","tags":[],"id":"25-2410808","$type":"Issue","workItems":[]}, {"created":1678485113968,"resolved":null,"attachments":[],"project":{"shortName":"IDEA","$type":"Project"},"updated":1688554495543,"reporter":{"login":"Jason_Breti","$type":"User"},"summary":"Add macro support for VM options field (e.g. expand $ModuleFileDir$ properly)","comments":[{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"ethan.yin","name":"Ethan Yin","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

Sample code:

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println(System.getProperty("test"));
    }
}

Add(pick up a macro from the 'insert macros' button) VM options in run configuration:
-Dtest=$MODULE_DIR$

Result:
$MODULE_DIR$ is not expanded.

Reproduced: #IU-232.6095
Not reproduced: #IU-231.8770.65

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Open several files in the editor
  2. Make sure horizontal scrollbars are available in the files
  3. Set the caret somewhere in the files, but not in the first column
  4. Reopen the project or restart the IDE
  5. Open each file and see how them scrolled

Expected result:
The files shouldn't be scrolled horizontally.

Actual result:
The files are scrolled horizontally, except the file selected on IDE opening:

What steps will reproduce the issue?
1. Given an existing project named (by default) after the project's directory name (e.g. rubymine-tester-61)
2. and within the directory, some file (e.g. Gemfile)
3. and rubymine doesn't have the project open
4. use the CLI to open the file e.g.: rubymine path-to/rubymine-tester-61/Gemfile

What is the expected result?

(Rubymine opens the project with the specific file open) and doesn't change the project name.

What happens instead?

Rubymine changes the project name to the name of the opened file (e.g. Gemfile)
this is true in the IDE and in the file .name in the .idea directory

Before

Closed

Once opened via rubymine Gemfile

After:

FYI I've seen this within 2021.3 so not specific to EAP.

","created":1669828432435,"updated":null,"id":"27-6685002","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Dmitrii.Naumenko","name":"Dmitrii Naumenko","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

We faced this restriction in Scala Plugin recently when improving quick documentation implementation for Scala (see SCL-20044)
We wanted to add definition location icon (package/class/object/etc...)
Right now only package works because we just use AllIcons.Nodes.Package
(we use <icon src="AllIcons.Nodes.Package"/>)

All other Scala-specific icons don't work.
I narrowed it down to ExtendableHTMLViewFactory.Extensions.IconsExtension#getIcon

","created":1688372345534,"updated":null,"id":"27-7637040","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"Dmitrii.Naumenko","name":"Dmitrii Naumenko","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

Right now ExtendableHTMLViewFactory.Extensions.IconsExtension#getIcon passes a hardcoded class to IconLoader.findIcon.
The classloader of this class is PathClassLoader with IntelliJ platform core jars.
This classloader is then used to load icons, which obviously fails for plugins.

To fix the issue, we could propagate the classloader of com.intellij.lang.documentation.DocumentationProvider implementation.
To quickly check if it helps, I tried to modify effectiveClassLoader in the debugger while rendering the documentation.
I set it to Scala Plugin classloader, and the documentation was able to pick up Scala-specific "object" icon:

@Vladimir Krivosheev please do fix this.

We don't call copyAdditionalFiles for performance reasons in Dev Server mode. Let's update copyAdditionalFiles to return a list of files for a copy with a destination instead of a direct copy. It allows us fast check it in dev-server mode.

The second problem occurs when I right-click on a folder (Folder A) that I want to open with IDE, and then when I close the IDE and start it again, it opens both the folder A and the folder B that I was working on before folder A.
However, as I said earlier, the first issue was solved, but it looked so wired when I came back to IDE the next day that this issue happened again; it still prompts me to choose a project when I open, and it looks like I need to delete the recentProjects.xml file every day.

","created":1678383650374,"updated":null,"id":"27-6953679","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"serge","name":"Serge Baranov","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

Reproduced by opening projects via command line (webstorm <project-path>).

Every time a project is opened this way, and then closed (IDE completely closed), a new entry is added to recentProjects.xml with opened="true" attribute.

If you then start the IDE normally (without specifying any project path in the arguments), it will reopen all the projects that were previously opened by providing the path via the command line (or file manager context menu).

Not sure if this behavior is by design or not. If it's not, the fix would be to remove opened="true" from all the recent projects (except the one being opened) when a new project is opened by providing its path to the IDE launcher.

","created":1678386372565,"updated":null,"id":"27-6953850","$type":"IssueComment"},{"deleted":false,"author":{"login":"1220.korng.samnang","name":"KORNG SAMNANG","$type":"User"},"textPreview":"

@Chester John ,

  1. Go to Help | Diagnostic Tools | Debug log settings... and type line #com.intellij.openapi.actionSystem.impl.ActionUpdater.
    Note: this setting will only be applied to the machine where you made it. Settings Sync will not sync it with the rest of your computers where you run IDE.
  2. Restart Idea
  3. Reproduce the problem
  4. Turn that debug setting off, and send us back the logs

What steps will reproduce the issue?
1. bring up ide create multiple edit windows on 2 screens (move an opened tab from main window to a separate (screen/graphics head) close IDE

2. open IDE, second window comes up for a few seconds and then disappears.
What is the expected result?

The second window should be as it was when the IDE was closed. (this was the old 2022.x version behavior)

What happens instead?

The second window comes up and then disappears.

Version tested on:

IntelliJ IDEA 2023.1 RC (Ultimate Edition)

Subscription is active until March 9, 2024.
